infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel

Class MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel.MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel
extends MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
implements MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, java.lang.Cloneable

    Computes the differential mutual information of two given multivariate sets of observations (implementing MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate), using box-kernel estimation. For details on box-kernel estimation, see Kantz and Schreiber (below).

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel().
    • Further properties are available, see setProperty(String, String);
    • An additional initialise(int, int, double) option;
    • Additional utility methods for computing other information-theoretic values are available here (e.g. computeAverageJointEntropy()) which can be called after all observations are supplied.

    TODO Use only a single kernel estimator class for the joint space, and compute other probabilities from this. This will save much time.

    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    "H. Kantz and T. Schreiber, 'Nonlinear Time Series Analysis'. Cambridge, MA: Cambridge University Press, 1997"

      • initialise

        public void initialise(int sourceDimensions,
              int destDimensions,
              double kernelWidth)
        Initialise the calculator for (re-)use, with a specific kernel width with number of source and destination joint variables specified, and existing (or default) values of other parameters,. Clears an PDFs of previously supplied observations.
        Parameters:
        sourceDimensions - the number of joint variables in the source
        destDimensions - the number of joint variables in the destination
        kernelWidth - if NORMALISE_PROP_NAME property has been set, then this kernel width corresponds to the number of standard deviations from the mean (otherwise it is an absolute value)

      • finaliseAddObservations

        public void finaliseAddObservations()
        Description copied from class: MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.

        This default implementation simply puts all of the observations into the MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.sourceObservations and MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.destObservations arrays. Usually child implementations will override this, call this implementation to perform the common processing, then perform their own processing.

        Specified by:
        finaliseAddObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Overrides:
        finaliseAddObservations in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the local values of the MI, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local MIs in bits
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] states1,
                                             double[][] states2)
        Compute the local MI values for each of the supplied samples in states1 and states2.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in states1 and states2 (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Calls to this method will not harness dynamic correlation exclusion (if set) since we don't know whether it's the same time set or not.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        states1 - series of multivariate observations for the source variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        states2 - series of multivariate observations for the destination variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the local values in bits. If the MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF property was set to say k, then the local values align with the destination value (i.e. after the given delay k). As such, the first k values of the array will be zeros.

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        protected double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] states1,
                                             double[][] states2,
                                             boolean isOurPreviousObservations)
        Protected utility function to compute the local MI values for each of the supplied samples in states1 and states2.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations. isOurPreviousObservations indicates whether those in states1 and states2 were some of the previously supplied samples.

        Parameters:
        states1 - provided source observations
        states2 - provided destination observations
        isOurPreviousObservations - whether these are our previous observations - this determines whether to add zeros for the first timeDiff local values, and also whether to set the internal lastAverage field, which is returned by later calls to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.getLastAverage()
        Returns:
        the local values in bits. If the MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF property was set to say k, then the local values align with the destination value (i.e. after the given delay k). As such, the first k values of the array will be zeros.

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception

        Set properties for the kernel MI calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • KERNEL_WIDTH_PROP_NAME (legacy value is EPSILON_PROP_NAME) -- kernel width to be used in the calculation. If normalise is set, then this is a number of standard deviations; otherwise it is an absolute value. Default is DEFAULT_KERNEL_WIDTH.
        • NORMALISE_PROP_NAME -- whether to normalise the incoming variables to mean 0, standard deviation 1, or not (default false). Sets normalise.
        • DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME_NAME -- a dynamics exclusion time window (see Kantz and Schreiber), default is 0 which means no dynamic exclusion window.
        • FORCE_KERNEL_COMPARE_TO_ALL -- whether to force the underlying kernel estimators to compare each data point to each other (or else allow it to use optimisations).
        • any valid properties for MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setProperty(String, String).

        Note that dynamic correlation exclusion (set with DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME_NAME) may have unexpected results if multiple observation sets have been added. This is because multiple observation sets are treated as though they are from a single time series, so observations from near the end of observation set i will be excluded from comparison to observations near the beginning of observation set (i+1).

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Overrides:
        setProperty in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • getKernelWidth

        public double getKernelWidth()
        Returns:
        the kernel width in use in the calculator

      • clone

        protected java.lang.Object clone()
                          throws java.lang.CloneNotSupportedException
        Clone the object - note: while it does create new cloned instances of the KernelEstimatorMultiVariate objects, I think these only have shallow copies to the data. This is enough though to maintain the structure across various MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.computeSignificance(int) calls.
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object
        Throws:
        java.lang.CloneNotSupportedException
        See Also:
        Object.clone()
